qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Scope: interpersonal and social relationships broadly

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Social media influences and shapes human behaviors.
Social media shapes how individuals perceive and interpret the world.
Social media impacts human communication in contemporary society.
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Digital Information & Communication in Contemporary Society
remarks: Communication here is interpreted as human communication in contemporary society, per canonical entity.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Social media is criticized for promoting superficial communication.
Social media use encourages or fosters prioritization of online relationships.
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Social Media and Online Social Interaction
remarks: Implicit relation; text attributes the tendency to the described social media context.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Social media is said to profoundly impact and shape human communication in contemporary society.
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Digital Information & Communication in Contemporary Society

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Social media affects human communication patterns in contemporary society.
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Digital Information & Communication in Contemporary Society

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: as we continue to navigate the landscape of social media
qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: ongoing engagement with social media platforms

args.canonical_rel_desc: Denotes that the subject exerts a causal or shaping effect on the object (e.g., social media influencing communication, relationships, behaviors, or perceptions).
args.justification: All relations describe social media having a shaping, impacting, encouraging, or promoting effect on various aspects of human life (communication, relationships, behaviors, perceptions). Despite surface verb differences (shapes, impacts, promotes, encourages), the underlying predicate is a causal influence from social media to the target domain, so they can be normalized to a single canonical predicate 'influences'.

Each relation instance links social media to some downstream social or communicative outcome (communication patterns, relationships, behaviors, perceptions, superficial or online-focused interaction). This is best modeled as a common class capturing the impact of social media on human and societal domains.

The rel_hint_type and descriptions consistently frame social media as having effects (impact, shaping, promoting, encouraging) on communication, relationships, and behavior, which is a causal influence pattern rather than mere association; thus they belong in a causal/impact-oriented group.

Despite surface verb differences (shapes, impacts, promotes, encourages), the underlying predicate is a causal influence from social media to the target domain, so they can be normalized to a single canonical predicate 'influences'.

Each relation instance links social media to some downstream social or communicative outcome (communication patterns, relationships, behaviors, perceptions, superficial or online-focused interaction). This is best modeled as a common class capturing the impact of social media on human and societal domains.

The rel_hint_type and descriptions consistently frame social media as having effects (impact, shaping, promoting, encouraging) on communication, relationships, and behavior, which is a causal influence pattern rather than mere association; thus they belong in a causal/impact-oriented group.
